Project RISHI

Project RISHI is a non-profit that aims to promote sustainable development in rural Indian communities. They use their site to connect with local community members and social enterprises to identify and find solutions for issues in target communities.

Roles: Researcher, visual designer

Skills: User interviews, empathy mapping, visual design, content writing

Resources: Live prototype

Date: Sep - Aug 2017

Teammates: Paulos Liu, Sandy Li, Henry Tran, Betty Zhou, Sen Fu, Derek Lee

Design Challenge

The previous ENG 100D team left us a website that showcased different projects in Project RISHI, along with feedback from the previous partner. We were tasked with improving and implementing an online map tool that shows the impact of Project RISHI's initiatives.

Research and User Needs

We graphed our stakeholders in a matrix to assess their influence on our poject, conducted secondary research, and made personas based on that. Since our client was Project RISHI as a whole, we reached out to executives of the organization and the school chapters after and were able talk to Anish Kazane, president of the UC Berkeley chapter.

In our initial correspondence, he wanted a map system that displays and filters information on projects and for it to be updatable. He said he wanted this in order to make it accessible for members to update the site and to ultimately better inform philanthropists and other site visitors on how they can get involved with Project RISHI. He also wanted the site to be a platform for training future members but said that he did not expect this from us or for it to happen for a while.

Problem Statement

To guide us towards a solution, we reframed the insights and pain points above into opportunities:

  • How might we make the site engaging so that it inspires philanthropists to contribute to or sponsor projects?
  • How might we make the site updatable and accessible for current and future members?

Interviews and Usability Tests

We conducted interviews and performed usability tests to determine users' engagement with the current Map feature and the site's overall pain points.

The Map feature on the site had filler text and items were missing or were not explained in the legend. Meanwhile, other pages had inconsistent styling and had Lorem Ipsum text. After tests we asked users what they understood about the site and users were generally confused due to the incomplete look and content of the Project RISHI's site at the time. Thus, users' experience prevented them from being able to empathize or even engage with any of the projects that the organization was doing.

Difficulties and Learning

One difficulty we faced in the project is consistent contact with stakeholders. We were not able to connect with as many Project RISHI representatives as we would have liked, and the contact we did have with the one chapter was not as consistent. Thus, once we had data from the meetings we did have, we ran with that and made designs and changes and performed usability tests on what we could.

The original prototype was hard coded using HTML, CSS, and Javascript. Because it was hard coded, it was difficult for any potential users to update, add, or remove information as needed, especially for the map feature. The coordinates themselves were entered using a file that Anish gave us. That made it difficult for members of Project RISHI to change the coordinates of each ward or potentially add new wards in the future.

Anish initially requested we develop using Ruby on Rails, so we switched to Drupal 7 since it made it easier for content to be updated through its prebuilt administrative framework. However, we felt as if Drupal 7 gave us very limited options for the appearance of the website, in addition to being very tedious and inflexible. Since user experience was one of the most important aspects of this project, we decided to use and update the old design from the previous quarter and deploy it onto another framework called Meteor.

Design decisions + Final Prototype

We wanted to keep the homepage simple and moved the Map feature to a different page and placed only the mission statement on the homepage. The map subsection of the toolbar includes map filters to show the regions on the rural Indian communities with icons to label the project's topic. Also, the map before had terrain of mountains and ridges removed since we believed it was insignificant and made readability harder.

We had content sent to us from other chapters for the About page. The Projects page listed individual projects and dropdown navigation on each topic in the map for consistency. We also included a Donate page for people wanting to contribute digitally. Because we decided to go with a coded page but wanted to address the need for teaching future members, we made some documentation.

View our live prototype to see our final design.
